posts.name: Ian Osborn
posts.cooked:
Looking to the offseason, I think our team learned some lessons about pre-designing core mechanisms. This allows time to be shifted to thinking about the game and working on game specific solutions vs. doing grunt work to just get a robot designed and built.

We designed the chassis around Mk4ns last summer - which allowed for just updating a couple numbers in a table to have the chassis parametrically change size. We used Thrift Bot’s elevator design as well. This allowed for more time to be spent on the intake/deposit and climber.

Looking back, having the chassis and elevator already “done” saved our bacon. The time we had could be spent on core gameplay decisions and designs vs foundational elements.

The team also saw how refined some of the robot designs are becoming - the take away lesson is that the designs are seasons old (2910, 1678, 5460, etc.) and they show this with the level of efficiency and refinement.

We don’t have 20 CAD capable kids running around, so we need to push work to the offseason.

Of course this also extends to the vision, controls, and software side of the robot. My educated guess is that Orbit’s object recognition has been developed over multiple seasons. 2767’s crazy Einstein auto worked because their localization is that good , again multiple seasons of work.

(This is my working thesis as to how the top teams keep raising the ceiling.)

So, this is what we’ve been kicking around for summer / fall projects for the CAD (and software) team.

Chassis - already have but can refine

Bumpers - tie this to the chassis parametrics.

Shooter & turret - “borrow” some of the better designs from 2022 and '20/21?

Elevator - continuous stringing

Pink arm & shoulder - ?

Spindexer - ?

Four-Bar intake (at least work out the drive)

Intake rollers (254’s concept)

Probably on the ambitious side, we’ll pare this down a bit I’m sure.

Wondering what projects other teams are going to take on along this line of thinking?

posts.name: Omer Prag
posts.cooked: I just have to correct the Orbit object detection part. We just use a mask within PV and run a simple trigonometric calculation on it. So nothing that was passed through multiple seasons.

posts.name: Andrew Torrance
posts.cooked:
I would recommend you look into the way 5940 BREAD did their intake rollers, as the TPU wheels were more robust than our foam, albiet a little bit heavier.

Spindexer? I’m assuming you’re referring to something like 2024 robot? Or our/others’ 2020 robots?

Among all of these the one I would prioritize is a hooded flywheel shooter as that is just such a common and important mechanism and if your team hasn’t done one then I’d pick that.

posts.name: Christoforus Cedric Kurniawan
posts.cooked: Maybe less CAD-projecty, but an idea I’ve been thinking over is using old game pieces and asking new members to design certain subsystems for them. For example, we have lots of Infinite Recharge and Rapid React game pieces, as well as cargo from Charged Up. One of my offseason training ideas was to ask newer members to test and create subsystems like intakes, shooters, end effectors, etc, for these old game pieces. Figured this would give them the best opportunity to learn the iteration and CAD process of making a subsystem.

posts.name: Ian Osborn
posts.cooked:
Ah cool

I suppose my point (and likely a poor assumption!) is that the basic architecture of your software has probably been stable for several seasons.

posts.name: Ian Osborn
posts.cooked: That’s a great idea! Make it more tactile.

posts.name: Hadi Al Sati
posts.cooked: So far we’re having people CAD individual mechanisms for this game, such as a vertical manipulator with an arm and we will CAD our chassis this offseason as well. As the offseason progresses we hope to CAD an entire robot during the summer, giving our Rockies and vets as much experience as possible

posts.name: Ian Osborn
posts.cooked:
Spindexer - A spinning indexer from 20/21 game. A method to sort foam nerf balls in a way that they don’t stick together and jam up the magazine. That game allowed 5 balls to be carried.

Similar sort of idea to the agitators or augers used in Steam Works.
